comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: Several other description (A), B), and C)) have been discussed during some of our meeting. Which description of "Demand" fits best in SC4EU? A) - Outgoing/ incoming Shipments (bound by capacity, mostly not directly forecasted, mostly historic values) B -  Outgoing (downstream)/ Incoming (upstream) Orders (already inflated and don’t reflect actual sales because of order cancellations) or C) - Confirmed orders.

comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: .. the recent definition originates from the Digital Reference Ontology

comments.author: Felix Engel

comments.author: Yannick Mester
comments.content: Maybe we can use: Past demand is the historical record of quantities of a product or service that customers requested or purchased over prior time periods, used as the basis for forecasting and planning

comments.author: Philipp Ulrich
comments.content: I would have it open with regards to quantities as demand could be measured in $ or € as well, even we do not do it right now. Other than that the definition by Yannick is good.

comments.author: Philippe Vialletelle
comments.content: Which is the difference between requested and purchased? What do we want to put behind that term? If it is "historical", i.e., one "single set of values" for a past date, I'd rather use "actual" than "past". From my stand point, past demand is multidimensional as I will have several sets of values (forecasted at different periods in the past) for the same past date.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: The difference between requested and purchased can be significant if product is on allocation, when inventories are low and capacity is fully utilized. So both are relevant and both can be informative for forecasting and planning

comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: Descritption is taken from WP5 meeting slides

comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: Alternative descriptions are: A) - Can be calculated by dividing the current inventory by the average orders a day for the next months B) - Result is the reach in days (Reach, Inventory Coverage, Days of Inventory)

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
True demand refers to the actual market need for a product, independent of any distortions caused by safety stocks, ordering behavior, or supply constraints.     In constrained situations, customer orders are not a good indicator of true demand.” Instead, demand visibility efforts aim to reconstruct or approximate true demand to support better planning and long-term capacity decisions . Understanding true demand is essential for: 
    Avoiding over- or under-capacity planning
    Smoothing production schedules
    Ensuring strategic alignment of resources

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: @Claude. Your description is better. My description is obsolete. Latest view is that True Demand = End Market Demand

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Maxi Udenio , @Philipp Ulrich

comments.author: Maxi Udenio
comments.content: Minor comment: there is a loose " after demand. I would separate the enumeration at the end with commas (planning, smoothing..., etc)

comments.author: Philipp Ulrich
comments.content: True demand refers to the actual end market need for a product. True demand is independent of any distortions caused by safety stocks, ordering behavior, or supply constraints traversing the supply chain. In constrained situations, customer orders are not a good indicator of true demand.” Instead, demand visibility efforts aim to reconstruct or approximate true demand to support better planning and long-term capacity decisions.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: I like Philipp's version

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: This represents the number of days, weeks, or months of future demand that the desired inventory level is expected to cover.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: The Pork Cycle is is een as a metaphor for boom-and-bust investment cycles caused by delayed supply responses to demand fluctuations. The result is the potential for large-scale boom and bust cycles reminiscent of the ‘pork cycle’ in agricultural economics.The delayed response of supply to demand, combined with uncertain forecasts and large capital requirements, gives rise to classic cyclicality.  It describes how overinvestment during shortages leads to future overcapacity, followed by price crashes and underinvestment, perpetuating the cycle.

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Robert Claude provided another definition. What do you think about it?

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: Claude's text is quite ok. It is not clear what 'classic cyclicality' means here. And the investments do not have to be large. And it only happens in industries that grow, such as semiconductors, or where the life time of capacity is limited, such as pork. And it can also happen if demand is stable (but that will only become clear after our article on the pork cycle has been published).

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Claude Yugma please have a look. Can you revise? @Maxi Udenio maybe you have some thoughts on it as well?

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Yannick Mester do you agree?

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Here is a revised version : The Pork Cycle is a metaphor for boom-and-bust investment patterns caused by delayed supply responses to demand conditions. It illustrates how shortages can trigger overinvestment, which later results in overcapacity, price declines, and underinvestment, perpetuating the cycle. This phenomenon typically occurs in industries where capacity has a limited lifetime (e.g., agriculture) or where growth and uncertainty make forecasts difficult (e.g., semiconductors).

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Yannick Mester @Maxi Udenio

comments.author: Maxi Udenio
comments.content: I like the 2nd definition!

comments.author: Yannick Mester
comments.content: I agree - 2nd version is fine

comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: I guess that "Desired Utilization Rate (DUR)" is rather a alternative label and "See Also". I have revised accordingly

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: @Felix There is Capacity, say 200 [u/t] and there is Utilization, say 160 [u/t], in which case Utilization Rate = 80%. There is a Desired Utilization Rate, say 90%, which is optimal from a plant and business point of view. Underutilization here is either 200-160 = 40 [u/t] or  (200-160)/200=20% or (180-160)/180 = 11%, depending on your definition. I go for the last.

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Maxi Udenio @Robert so I guess the definition needs to be adapted? Or maybe the Alternative Lable as well?

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: The alternative label should be deleted. DUR can be mentioned under "See Also:"

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: Underutilization is not using part of capacity, and can be defined versus Capacity or versus Desired Utilization Rate and it can be expressed as a percentage or in capacity units. Capacity can be Nameplate capacity, Maximum Capacity or Effective Capacity.

comments.author: Maxi Udenio
comments.content: Agree with Robert. I'm not familiar how the term is used in the industry though. By definition, no process can ever run at 100% utilization rate in practice, so in that sense (against technical maximal capacity) there is always underutilization. I would take Robert's suggestion and use whatever is common in the industry.

comments.author: felix
comments.content: Robert proposed a different definition: "Estimating a smooth trend, usually be taking weighted averages of observations. The term smoothed is used because such averages tend to reduce randomness by allowing positive and negative random effects to partially offset each other."

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: The bullwhip effect refers to demand distortions that amplify as information moves upstream in the supply chain, often due to forecast updates, order batching, and demand signal processing.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Short-term demand refers to forecasted or actual demand over a short planning horizon—typically days or weeks. It is used for near-term scheduling and order fulfilment decisions.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
Semantic technology refers to a set of technologies that enable machines to understand, interpret, and reason about data through its meaning rather than just its structure.
In the semiconductor supply chain context, semantic technologies help integrate diverse data sources, improve interoperability, and support decision-making by linking data through shared vocabularies and ontologies.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Curation refers to the activity of cleaning, validating, or processing data within the supply chain. It ensures that data (such as orders, inventory, customers, etc.) are complete, accurate, and usable.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: I propose to adopt Claude's

comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: It is somewhat lengthy, but as such hopefully explanatory

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
These are standardized frameworks developed by the W3C to support the development of the Semantic Web. They include RDF (Resource Description Framework), OWL (Web Ontology Language), and SPARQL (query language).
In the documents, these standards underpin efforts to create digitally interoperable supply chains using structured knowledge models. These concepts support advanced systems like decision support, supply chain analytics, and digital twins by enriching raw data with context and relationships.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: there is no description. SHall we delete?

comments.author: Robert
comments.content:
The description still does not say what a Semantic Web is. It is helping and it has a goal. It refers to a vision of linked data. But what is said vision? What are rules for handling data? 

And who is W3C?

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
The Semantic Web is an extension of the current web that enables data to be shared and reused across applications, enterprises, and communities by attaching meaning (semantics) to the data.
It plays a role in the digital reference ontologies mentioned in the documents, supporting intelligent data access and reasoning in distributed systems.

comments.content: "A semiconductor fabrication plant (commonly called a fab; sometimes foundry) is a factory for semiconductor device fabrication." (wiki). This is correct in my view. The DR description is nonsense.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: A fab (short for fabrication plant) is a manufacturing facility where semiconductor wafers are processed to produce integrated circuits.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: A fab (short for fabrication plant) is a manufacturing facility where semiconductor wafers (discs containing integrated circuits) are produced.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
Robert’s revision makes the text more accessible, but I think it blurs an important distinction: fabs do not produce wafers, but rather process silicon wafers to create integrated circuits on them.

For accuracy while keeping it simple, a compromise could be:
“A fab (short for fabrication plant) is a manufacturing facility where silicon wafers are processed to create integrated circuits (ICs).”

This keeps the technical precision while still being understandable.

comments.author: Maxi Udenio
comments.content: Again, can't comment on the details of the process, but I'm inclined to go for the latest definition, which is accessible and fully technical at the same time.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
Front end" refers to the initial phases of the production process, primarily wafer fabrication and wafer probe.
These stages involve creating the integrated circuits on silicon wafers using processes like photolithography, doping, etching, and deposition. Wafer fabrication and probe are generally referred to as front-end operations.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: efers to the assembly and test stages of semiconductor manufacturing, typically occurring after wafer fabrication (front end).

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: A CUSTOMER LOGISTICS MANAGEMENT REPRESENTATIVE (CLM) is a typical name for one “face” to the customer, taking care of all customers supply chain topics. He/she is responsible for the demand fulfilment process – Usage of ATP. It is his/her task to ensure in-time delivery to customers based on orders and forecasts. He/she is usually also taking care of forecast in a midterm time horizon (typical for that is the EDI FORECAST)

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: MARKETING DEMAND is a supply chain or production request for a specific product, product group or service, coming from the market. Either demand exists explicitly in form of customer need (e.g. orders or EDI forecast) or implicitly as expected customer need.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: A nEW is a negative Early Warning and it means that a new customer order confirmation is worse (later order confirmation date) than the previous order confirmation. nEWs is the plural of nEW

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: OPERATIONAL DEMAND is a supply chain or production request for a specific product, product group or service, coming from company intern business division. Either demand exists explicitly in form of customer need (e.g. orders or EDI forecast) or implicitly as expected customer need.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: Any change in the requested order delivery date or volume in an order line is referred to as an order rescheduling.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Planning refers to the set of activities aimed at aligning supply capabilities with demand requirements over different time horizons, under constraints of capacity, material availability, and manufacturing lead times. Planning activities attempt to reconcile the demand picture with the supply picture to ensure delivery of committed products and optimize fab performance.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: PLANNING is an activity with the purpose to determine a plan. Planning is associated with goals, represented by objective functions to be optimized.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content:
In the planning domain a PLANNING CONSTRAINTS is often referred to capacity limitation, which limit the quantities that can be produced on an equipment or a fab for a certain product or product groups. Other Constraints can be workforce or material. Constraints can be temporary and can change. 
Most popular academic definition: A PLANNING CONSTRAINT restricts the action space. This space is formed by alternative actions that are a result of the planning decisions (Schneeweis 2003).

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: The PLANNING DECISIONS is the best choice out of options, determined by the DECISION-MAKING UNIT.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: delete

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: HIERARCHICAL SITUATION refers to the structured, multi-level arrangement of entities, processes, or decision-making authority within the supply chain. It outlines e.g. how different layers—such as suppliers, manufacturers, distributors, and retailers—interact based on levels of control, responsibility, and information flow.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: FROZEN FENCE is used to set a frozen interval in which decision making is not allowed, or a defined exception, to change the previously determined values.

comments.content: A PROCESS is a collection of subprocesses that meet a specific business objective. E.g. Perform Sourcing or Purchase Materials and Services. A production PROCESS specifies a method of making a product at a location. The process is expressed at a coarse level of granularity suitable for use in production planning.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: A PROMISE is the committed portion of supply by the master production schedule and material plan.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Sales demand refers to the quantity of a product that the sales organization expects to sell or has committed to sell over a given period. It may include firm customer orders, sales forecasts, or strategic targets.

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Maxi Udenio @Philipp Ulrich any comments on the revised definition?

comments.author: Maxi Udenio
comments.content: I'm not familiar with this concept. This seems to me to be the "sales forecast" maintained by the sales division of a company, which typically includes advanced information. If so, this looks good. It may be interesting to include the explicit difference to "actual" sales coming from the true demand.

comments.author: Philipp Ulrich
comments.content:
I like the definition of Claude as a baseline. I would only add that the sales demand is actually the unbound demand from our point of view, so this is what we could sell to customers IF we have unlimited manufacturing capacities (which we dont ;) )

So Sales demand is quite high and is the baseline to derive what will be produced.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: A SALES DEMAND is a request for a specific product or service that can have different triggers. Either demand exists explicitly in form of customer orders or implicitly as expected customer need that have to be fulfilled by the semiconductor supply chain.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
Supply-demand match refers to the alignment between what is available (supply) and what is needed (demand), considering timing, quantities, and product configurations.
In constrained environments, this matching process often requires optimization to balance competing priorities, such as customer service level and inventory efficiency.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
The supply picture is a representation of the total available and projected supply both inventory and production over a planning horizon.
It provides visibility for planners to assess whether and how current and planned supply can meet demand.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: A SUPPLY PICTURE is a visualization of the supply in its dimensions. Supply is the total amount of specific products that is available to customers. Supply has the dimensions quantity, time, location, product, including aggregation of all dimensions. Supply is defined as inventory or plan replenishment.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
A target refers to a defined objective or performance goal in the supply chain such as desired inventory levels, service levels, or utilization rates.
Targets guide decision-making in planning, allocation, and scheduling.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: VERTEX plays a crucial role in the financial and compliance side of the supply chain. Its solutions help businesses calculate, manage, and report indirect taxes (like sales tax, VAT, and GST) at the relevant point in the supply chain, from procurement to distribution.

comments.author: Eelco Debeij
comments.content: In the context of semiconductors, a technology or process node refers to the manufacturing technology used to fabricate integrated circuits (ICs), typically expressed in nanometers (nm). It historically indicated the minimum feature size (such as the gate length of a transistor) that could be reliably produced on a chip. However, in modern semiconductor manufacturing, the term has become more of a marketing label than a precise physical measurement. Today, process node names (e.g., 5 nm, 3 nm) represent a generation of technology rather than an exact dimension. They often imply improvements in: transistor density (more transistors per unit area), performance (higher speed, lower power consumption), power efficiency (better energy per operation).

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
In the supply chain context, time is a key dimension across all planning activities, representing lead times, cycle times, delivery windows, and time fences for freezing plans.
Time is often segmented into discrete buckets (e.g., daily, weekly, monthly) for operational and strategic planning.

comments.content: Allocation refers to the process of assigning available supply to customer orders, especially when demand exceeds supply. It is often governed by predefined rules or priorities to manage shortages effectively.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: A CUSTOMER PLANT refers to the physical location or facility owned or operated by a customer where products, systems, or services are delivered, installed, maintained, or utilized.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: CUSTOMER PLANT DATA refers to the structured and unstructured information associated with a customer's plant.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: DELIVERY COMMITMENT refers to the agreed-upon date or timeframe by which a product, service, or solution is promised to be delivered to a customer. It is a key component of supply chain, project management, and customer service operations, ensuring alignment between supplier capabilities and customer expectations.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: The DELIVERY CONCEPT defines the terms and conditions for delivering an order to the customer. Partial and split delivery has to be taken into account.

comments.content: Demand trace is the tracking of demand from final customer requests through the supply chain, enabling visibility of demand origins and fulfillment status.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: The IN-TRANSIT INVENTORY describes the quantity of a certain product that is shipped from one location to another. This quantity has left the inventory of one location, but has not yet been received into the inventory of the receiving location.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: INVENTORY refers to the stock of goods, materials, and components that a business holds for the purpose of production, resale, or operational use. It is a key asset in supply chain and financial management, directly impacting a company's ability to meet customer demand, manage costs, and generate revenue.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: OPEN ORDER refers to a customer order that has been received and recorded in the system but has not yet been fully processed, shipped, or fulfilled. It represents a pending obligation within the sales or supply chain process.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: An ORDER CHANGE REQUEST is a formal request initiated by a customer or internal stakeholder to modify an existing order after it has been placed but before it is fully fulfilled or invoiced. This request can include changes to product quantities, item specifications, delivery dates, shipping addresses, or other order-related details.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: ORDER CONFIRMATION is a formal acknowledgment from the seller to the customer that an order has been received, reviewed, and accepted under the specified terms and conditions.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: The mean absolute percentage error is the average of the sum of the absolute values of the percentage differences between forecasted data and the actuals. Forecast Accuracy = 1 - MAPE, is a measure of accuracy commonly used as a KPI for quantitative methods of forecasting. MAPE needs a specification of the time period that it refers to (e.g. januari 2027, or the 12 months of 2027) and the time lag for the forecast (e.g. made three months earlier).

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: An S-curve refers to the characteristic shape of product adoption or technology diffusion over time, typically showing slow initial growth, rapid acceleration, and eventual saturation.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: An ORDER LINE ITEM is an individual entry within a customer order that specifies the details of a specific product or service being purchased. Each line item represents a unique combination of product, quantity, and pricing, and collectively, line items make up the full contents of an order. A new order line item might be generated when partial fulfillment is committed or delivered.

comments.content: Every product on the order is referenced by a record that includes quantity and usually a customer delivery wish date, as well as a reference to which order it belongs.

Performance measures must reflect the objectives of the supply chain including customer service, inventory levels, response times, and capacity utilization.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: A PRODUCT AGGREGATE combines individual products into a product group, called a PRODUCT AGGREGATE. This results in a reduction of complexity, which enables a better overview.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: A PRODUCT HIERARCHY characterizes the top-down and bottom-up relationship between different product aggregates. It organizes the product aggregates according to defined criteria. A product aggregate is used to group different products based on certain criteria. The grouping criteria depends often on the planning purpose (e.g. controlling, production). It is a certain view on a set of products.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
Demand fulfilment refers to the set of processes by which a company responds to customer demand by delivering products or services. In the semiconductor supply chain, it includes order promising, product allocation, scheduling, and ensuring timely delivery.
It represents the interface between the supply chain and external customers, ensuring that demand is met in accordance with business rules and available resources. It represents the interface between the supply chain and its external customers.”
It also connects closely with Available to Promise (ATP) mechanisms that decide what can be committed to customers based on current and projected inventory and capacity.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: A demand snapshot is a fixed capture of demand data at a given point in time. It allows comparison over time or alignment between supply and demand planning cycles.

comments.author: Infineon Admin
comments.content: OPEN ORDER BOOK refers to a real-time record of all active, unfulfilled customer orders within an organization. It includes detailed information on sales orders.

comments.content: An OWNER refers to the individual, team, or entity that holds primary responsibility for a specific asset, process, task, or decision within an organization or project.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: A supply chain is the network of organizations, resources, activities, and technologies involved in the production and delivery of a product from raw materials to the final customer. Supply chain management issues have become increasingly important to the semiconductor industry due to the global distribution of facilities and increasing numbers of firms specialising in particular stages.

comments.content: A partner refers to any external organization that collaborates within the supply network, such as foundries, OSATs (outsourced semiconductor assembly and test providers), EDA tool vendors, equipment suppliers, or logistics providers.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Wafer fabrication is the core front-end process in semiconductor manufacturing where integrated circuits (ICs) are created on the surface of silicon wafers. It is also seen as the process by which ICs are produced is one of the most complex technological achievements of the twentieth century… A CMOS manufacturing process of even modest complexity can involve hundreds of unit operations, up to forty layers of material, several hundred individual pieces of production equipment (referred to as tools), and average cycle times of the order of 10–15 weeks

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: If production takes more than 6 months, isn't  cycle time than >26 weeks?

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Claude Yugma thoughs?

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
That’s a very good point. I think the key here is the distinction between cycle time and overall production lead time.

Cycle time usually refers to the effective processing time of a wafer lot as it moves through all required unit operations in the fab. For a CMOS process, this is often reported as ~10–15 weeks.

However, the lead time experienced by customers can be much longer (sometimes >26 weeks), because it includes queueing, waiting for equipment availability, rework loops, engineering holds, and sometimes supply-related delays.

So while the process cycle time is on the order of 10–15 weeks, the total time from release to delivery can easily extend to six months or more.

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Robert @Maxi Udenio

comments.author: Maxi Udenio
comments.content:
True. I'm not an expert in the fabrication process so I can't comment on the estimates. 

Maybe it's good to add entries (if they are not there yet?) separating cycle times and lead times? Then we can use these with precision whenever they are needed. A key distinction, I think, is that lead times are variable and a function of utilization, whereas cycle times refer to the physical processing.
